thread.title_full: Passengers drag ranting man from London bus after he 'punched and kicked ticket inspector'

author: Chloe Chaplain
title: Passengers drag ranting man from London bus after he 'punched and kicked ticket inspector'
text:
Tuesday 7 March 2017 08:14 GMT Click to followThe Evening Standard Suspect: The man had allegedly assaulted the ticket inspector Metropolitan police 
A ranting man was dragged off a bus by a group of passengers after he attacked the ticket inspector who had challenged him for not paying the fare. 
The inspector asked the man to leave the bus after he refused to pay for his trip on the Route 149 bus in north London . 
The man then allegedly launched an attack on the inspector, repeatedly kicking him in the legs and punching him in the head and chest. 
Members of the public travelling on the same bus jumped to the inspector's defence and grabbed the man, forcing him off the vehicle. 
As he was pushed off, the man shouted threats at the ticket inspector, saying: "The next time I see you, you will be a dead man." Assault: The bus was travelling towards Manse Road at the time of the incident (Google Maps) 
Police appealing for information about the alleged attack have released an image of a man they would like to speak with in connection with the incident. Meat cleaver seized by police from grounds of south-east London school 
Officers from the Met's roads and transport unit have asked for witnesses of the assault - which took place on January 5 at 1.20pm near Manse Road - to come forward. 
PC Neil Webb said: "We robustly investigate all allegations of assault that occur on the bus network. If you commit such an offence, not only will you be prosecuted, but you may also be banned from being able to use TfL operated services in the future." 
A police appeal described the suspect as a stocky black man, approximately 5ft 10ins tall, 40-years-old, with a black moustache and a London accent. 
Graham Daley, TfL's head of enforcement and on-street operations, said: "Our staff have the right to go about their work without fear or intimidation. 
â€œWe are extremely concerned by these allegations and urge anyone with information to come forward to police." 
Anyone with information is asked to contact PC Neil Webb on 07500 607652 or Crimestoppers anonymously on 0800 555 111. More about:
